name: Psychiatry - General (Adult Inpatient & Outpatient)

points: High patient load with limited time per encounter, leading to rushed evaluations
Overbooked schedules for medication management visits with minimal support
Growing complexity of cases (dual diagnosis, treatment-resistant depression, comorbidities)
Insufficient time for therapy or psychosocial interventions
Administrative pressure to increase productivity despite burnout risks
Limited access to therapists, case managers, and social workers for coordinated care
Shortage of psychiatric nurses and APPs, increasing physician burden
Delayed access to inpatient beds and crisis stabilization resources
Fragmented discharge planning processes impacting continuity of care
Compensation not aligned with time spent on complex cases and documentation
RVU-based models discouraging adequate session length for complex patients
No credit for non-billable duties such as family meetings or care coordination
Opaque or inconsistent bonus metrics tied to throughput or satisfaction scores
Emotional exhaustion from high-acuity or chronic patients
Limited schedule flexibility for personal wellness or family obligations
Call demands and consults after hours impacting recovery time
Increased administrative work due to medication pre-authorizations
Insufficient mental health resources even for providers themselves
EHR documentation redundancy and slow systems reducing efficiency
Inconsistent communication between psychiatry, primary care, and specialists
Limited telepsychiatry infrastructure or technical support
Pressure to see more patients without additional staff or workflow improvements

motivations: Predictable schedule with manageable patient volumes
Balanced workload between med management and therapeutic time
Access to interdisciplinary team support (therapists, social work, case managers)
Transparent compensation aligned with clinical complexity and quality care
Reduced administrative burden and optimized EMR tools
Opportunities for leadership (Medical Director, Chief of Psychiatry, QI roles)
Hybrid telepsychiatry and on-site work options
Stable inpatient or outpatient focus with clear expectations
Culture prioritizing physician wellness and burnout prevention
Geographic relocation or family lifestyle improvement
Opportunities for teaching or resident supervision
Adequate call coverage and support for crisis situations

opening: Tell me about your current psychiatric practice—outpatient, inpatient, or a combination?
What’s motivating you to explore new opportunities right now?
What are the top changes you’d like to see in your next role?
painDiscovery: You mentioned [pain point]—how is that affecting your daily schedule and patient interactions?
Where do you experience the most friction—documentation, patient load, or staffing gaps?
How has your call or consult volume impacted your ability to recharge?
What kind of support (therapists, APPs, case managers) would make the biggest difference for you?
If you could change one operational process tomorrow, what would it be and why?
clinical: Describe your typical patient mix—depression, anxiety, bipolar, psychosis, dual-diagnosis, etc.
How many patients do you typically see per day, and what’s your ideal workload?
Do you currently manage both med management and therapy, or primarily pharmacologic care?
Tell me about your call schedule—how often and what type of coverage is expected?
What’s your comfort level with telepsychiatry and virtual patient management?
How do you handle crisis stabilization, involuntary holds, or inpatient transitions?
What does your interdisciplinary team look like, and what improvements would you like to see?
Are you interested in leadership or academic involvement in your next position?
motivation: When you picture your ideal psychiatric practice, what stands out—patient mix, schedule, or culture?
What factors would make a move clearly worthwhile for you and your family?
Which priorities rank highest for you—schedule control, compensation, or team support?
What elements would make your next environment feel more fulfilling than your current one?
compensation: Walk me through your current compensation model—base, productivity, stipends, and bonuses.
Do you feel your current structure fairly reflects your workload and case complexity?
What compensation range and model would make a new opportunity attractive to you?

commonChallenges.challenge: My patient load is too high to provide quality care.
commonChallenges.response: What daily volume feels sustainable, and how do you define a balanced schedule for yourself?

commonChallenges.challenge: I’m struggling with burnout and emotional fatigue.
commonChallenges.response: What kinds of schedule adjustments or support systems would help you recover and thrive?

commonChallenges.challenge: Compensation doesn’t reflect the complexity of my cases.
commonChallenges.response: Would a hybrid model—base plus quality or complexity metrics—better fit your expectations?

commonChallenges.challenge: I feel isolated and lack team collaboration.
commonChallenges.response: What team composition or interdisciplinary setup would enhance your day-to-day experience?

commonChallenges.challenge: I want to move into more telepsychiatry or leadership opportunities.
commonChallenges.response: What balance of clinical versus administrative or remote work would you find ideal?
If documentation support or EMR streamlining were implemented, how would that impact your satisfaction?

challengingOpportunities: You mentioned burnout—if a new role offered a capped daily schedule with strong team support, would that address your core concern?
You prefer outpatient-only—if we structured a hybrid with flexible telepsychiatry and minimal inpatient time, would that fit your goals?
If compensation is the key issue, would a transparent plan with quality bonuses and wellness incentives meet your expectations?
You said administrative work is draining—if a practice invested in scribes and EHR optimization, would that improve your quality of life?
